study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide recommendations for managing coeliac disease and other gluten-related disorders, focusing on the role of a gluten-free diet in treatment.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet is the primary treatment for coeliac disease, requiring patient education and follow-up, with slow responsiveness noted in adults. It also addressed other gluten-related disorders, such as dermatitis herpetiformis and non-coeliac gluten sensitivity, highlighting symptom improvement with gluten withdrawal.
population_specificity: Adults and children with coeliac disease and other gluten-related disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review therapeutic options, including a gluten-free diet, for managing dermatitis herpetiformis, a cutaneous manifestation of celiac disease.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet effectively controls dermatitis herpetiformis, often in combination with dapsone, but did not provide specific efficacy metrics.
population_specificity: Patients with dermatitis herpetiformis (a subset of celiac disease patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the rate of adherence to a gluten-free diet (GFD) in children with celiac disease, identify risk factors affecting adherence, and assess outcomes of non-adherence.
results_summary: The study found substantial variation in GFD adherence rates (23%-98%), with median adherence rates of 75%-87% regardless of assessment method. Non-adherence was linked to poorer growth, symptoms, and quality of life, while better adherence was associated with parental knowledge about celiac disease.
population_specificity: Children diagnosed with celiac disease (7,850 participants across 49 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet (GFD) in treating dermatitis herpetiformis (DH) and its associated small bowel mucosal damage, as well as its impact on quality of life and lymphoma risk.
results_summary: The study found that a strict, lifelong GFD effectively alleviates DH symptoms, heals small bowel mucosal damage, improves quality of life, and reduces lymphoma risk. However, GFD has a slow effect on the DH rash, necessitating additional treatment with dapsone for severe cases.
population_specificity: Adults diagnosed with dermatitis herpetiformis (DH), slightly more common in males.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence for the use of a gluten-free diet (GFD) in non-celiac conditions, including non-celiac gluten sensitivity, athletic performance, autism, rheumatoid arthritis, and psychiatric disorders.
results_summary: The study found that evidence supporting the use of GFDs for conditions other than celiac disease is poor, with many patients having alternative diagnoses after investigation. The abstract also highlights potential physical and psychological harms of unnecessary gluten avoidance.
population_specificity: Individuals without celiac disease who self-report intestinal or extraintestinal symptoms, as well as those seeking athletic enhancement or treatment for autism, rheumatoid arthritis, or psychiatric disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the metabolic effects of a gluten-free diet over 6 months in patients with celiac disease, nonceliac gluten sensitivity, and asymptomatic controls.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet increased obesity and metabolic syndrome in celiac patients by 20%, increased obesity by 5% and hepatic steatosis by 20% in NCGS patients, and decreased obesity by 10% in asymptomatic controls without affecting other metabolic syndrome components.
population_specificity: 66 subjects (22 celiac disease, 22 nonceliac gluten sensitivity, 22 asymptomatic controls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the efficacy of dietary interventions, including a gluten-free diet, in managing psoriasis.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet was efficacious in improving psoriasis symptoms, though the results were mixed. It was noted as a potentially important adjunct to first-line treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with psoriasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess dietary intake, clinical symptoms, and health-related quality of life in adults with self-reported non-coeliac gluten sensitivity (NCGS) on a gluten-free diet (GFD).
results_summary: Subjects on a GFD had high fat intake and suboptimal levels of vitamin D, folic acid, calcium, iodine, and iron. Despite dietary adjustments, they reported persistent gastrointestinal and extra-intestinal symptoms and reduced quality of life.
population_specificity: 65 adults with self-reported NCGS on a GFD, excluding coeliac disease and wheat allergy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the existence, diagnostic criteria, and management of non-celiac gluten and/or wheat sensitivity (NCGS) and the role of a gluten-free diet in alleviating symptoms.
results_summary: The abstract highlights skepticism about NCGS as a distinct disorder, noting the lack of strict diagnostic criteria and variability in study results due to patient perception and nocebo effects. It suggests a multidisciplinary approach and potential benefits of eliminating high-gluten and high-fructan foods.
population_specificity: Patients with suspected non-celiac gluten and/or wheat sensitivity (NCGS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a gluten-free diet improves psychiatric, cognitive, and gastrointestinal symptoms in individuals with schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder who have elevated anti-gliadin antibodies (AGA IgG).
results_summary: Participants on the gluten-free diet showed improvements in negative symptoms and attention, as well as robust reductions in gastrointestinal adverse effects, compared to those on the gluten-containing diet. No significant improvements were observed in positive or global cognitive symptoms.
population_specificity: Individuals with schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder who had elevated AGA IgG but were negative for celiac disease.
effective_dosage: 10 g of gluten flour or rice flour daily via a shake.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the performance of ELISA and point-of-care tests for detecting gluten immunogenic peptides (GIP) excretion in celiac disease patients on a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that GIP tests detected dietary transgressions in 25% of patients on a long-term gluten-free diet, with higher detection rates in asymptomatic (32%) than symptomatic (15.8%) patients. GIP results were concordant with dietary reports in 65.9% of cases.
population_specificity: Celiac disease patients following a gluten-free diet for at least two years.
study_duration: Samples and dietary reports were obtained 10 days apart.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of an organic durum wheat variety (Senatore Cappelli) versus standard commercial wheat on symptoms in patients with non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS).
results_summary: Patients reported lower overall symptom scores after consuming Senatore Cappelli pasta compared to standard pasta, suggesting a potential difference in symptom triggers between wheat varieties. The study involved a double-blind randomized cross-over design with 34 completers.
population_specificity: 42 patients (70.6% female, mean age 45) with NCGS diagnosed per Salerno criteria and adhering to a gluten-free diet for at least 12 weeks prior.
effective_dosage: Two-week diet periods with each pasta type (Senatore Cappelli and standard commercial).
study_duration: Two weeks per treatment arm, with a two-week washout period in between.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of supplementing a gluten-free diet (GFD) with prebiotic oligofructose-enriched inulin (Synergy 1) on the concentration of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in the urine of children and adolescents with celiac disease.
results_summary: Supplementing GFD with Synergy 1 for 12 weeks resulted in a 36% average drop in benzaldehyde concentration in urine samples, indicating a moderate impact on VOC levels. The study identified and quantified 16 compounds in urine but did not report broader clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with celiac disease (n=23).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the current state of celiac disease (CD) diagnosis and treatment patterns, including the role of a gluten-free diet (GFD).
results_summary: The study found that strict adherence to a GFD is the only recommended treatment for CD, though it is not successful in all patients. Barriers to diagnosis and treatment include atypical presentation, lack of physician awareness, and limited access to specialists.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease (CD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current understanding of celiac disease, including its diagnosis and the role of a gluten-free diet as the primary treatment.
results_summary: The study highlights that a strict gluten-free diet is the mainstay treatment for celiac disease, with serologic testing (tTG IgA) showing high sensitivity and specificity for diagnosis. The abstract notes the varied presentations of celiac disease, from gastrointestinal symptoms to extra-intestinal manifestations.
population_specificity: Patients over 2 years of age with celiac disease or suspected celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prevalence and clinical outcomes of neurological manifestations (neuropathy and ataxia) in patients with celiac disease (CD) and the impact of a gluten-free diet on these symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that gluten neuropathy was a common neurological manifestation in CD (up to 39% prevalence), while gluten ataxia was less prevalent (0%–6%). Adherence to a gluten-free diet appeared to improve symptoms of both neuropathy and ataxia.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease experiencing neurological manifestations (neuropathy and/or ataxia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of gluten-free diets (GFD) on gut microbiota modulation in pathological conditions like celiac disease (CD) and irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: The abstract suggests that GFD can have beneficial effects on disease symptoms but may also alter gut microbiota composition, especially with prolonged use. Few studies have explored these effects in detail.
population_specificity: Individuals with pathological conditions such as CD, IBS, or neurological disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the clinical presentations, diagnostic challenges, and treatment efficacy of gluten-related disorders, particularly non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS), and the role of a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that NCGS lacks precise diagnostic tests or biomarkers, requiring a cumbersome gluten-exposure protocol for diagnosis. Symptoms improve on a gluten-free diet, but recent data suggest other wheat components, like fructans, may also trigger symptoms, indicating the term "gluten sensitivity" may be too restrictive.
population_specificity: Children and adults with functional gastrointestinal complaints, particularly those with NCGS.
study_duration: Several weeks to months of gluten avoidance

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current knowledge on environmental risk factors for coeliac disease (CD) and their interactions, focusing on how these factors influence CD risk beyond gluten ingestion.
results_summary: The study highlights that CD risk is influenced by multiple environmental factors, including childhood infections, gut microbiota variability, and dietary factors, which primarily act by disrupting intestinal permeability. A strict, lifelong gluten-free diet is effective for managing CD in diagnosed patients.
population_specificity: Genetically susceptible individuals, particularly those with coeliac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of oligofructose-enriched inulin supplementation on bone metabolism and immune response in children with celiac disease on a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: Supplementation with oligofructose-enriched inulin increased osteocalcin levels (indicating improved bone formation) and stabilized pyridinoline levels (reducing bone resorption), while immunological responses remained unchanged. The placebo group showed increased bone resorption markers, highlighting the potential benefits of prebiotic supplementation.
population_specificity: Children with celiac disease on a gluten-free diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize knowledge about the effect of dietary interventions, including gluten-free diet, on patient-reported outcomes and inflammation in patients with fibromyalgia.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results for gluten-free diet, only mentioning it as one of the dietary approaches studied among seven clinical trials.
population_specificity: Patients with fibromyalgia (FM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of a gluten-free diet (GFD) as the sole treatment for celiac disease (CD) and its impact on nutritional status and quality of life.
results_summary: The study found that a GFD is the only effective treatment for CD, addressing nutritional deficiencies and improving long-term health outcomes. It also highlighted the importance of dietitian support for managing nutritional status and nonresponsive CD.
population_specificity: Individuals with celiac disease (CD), including untreated or newly diagnosed patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the nutritional profile of gluten-free-rendered products and discuss their possible relationship with the nutritional status of coeliac patients on a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that gluten-free products often have low protein content and high fat and salt content, though dietary fiber and sugar levels have improved. Population studies confirmed these nutritional inadequacies, highlighting the need for better product development.
population_specificity: Coeliac disease patients on a gluten-free diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a strict gluten-free diet in achieving symptomatic, serologic, and histologic remission in patients with celiac disease.
results_summary: The study found that a strict gluten-free diet leads to remission in most patients, with complete histologic remission more common in children than adults. Yearly follow-up is recommended for all age groups after remission is achieved.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease (children, adolescents, and adults).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the persistence of malnutrition and intestinal villous atrophy in refractory celiac disease (RCD) despite a strict gluten-free diet, and to differentiate between RCD subtypes (RCDI and RCDII).
results_summary: The study found that refractory celiac disease (RCD) persists despite a strict gluten-free diet, with RCDII having a poor prognosis due to abnormal intraepithelial lymphocytes (IELs) and a high risk of lymphoma.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease who developed refractory celiac disease (RCD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the macronutrient and dietary fibre composition of gluten-free products (GFP) and gluten-containing counterparts (GCC) available in Spain.
results_summary: GCC had higher protein content than GFP, especially in flour, bread, pasta, and pizza. GFP, particularly bread, had higher total and saturated fat contents, with palm oil being the main fat used. The study concluded that GFP are not equivalent substitutes for GCC and recommended reformulation with healthier ingredients.
population_specificity: Food products available in Spain (621 GFP and 600 GCC).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study analyzed food composition, not dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of a gluten-free diet as the only effective treatment for coeliac disease and its challenges in diagnosis and adherence.
results_summary: The study found that a lifelong strict gluten-free diet is the only effective treatment for coeliac disease, though it is restrictive and difficult to maintain. The clinical presentation of coeliac disease is highly variable, making diagnosis challenging.
population_specificity: Individuals with coeliac disease or suspected coeliac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a gluten-free diet (GFD) on gastrointestinal symptoms in subjects with functional gastrointestinal disorders (FGIDs), particularly irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: Most prospective studies found GFD improved gastrointestinal symptoms in FGIDs/IBS patients, but results were inconsistent due to study design variations, including gluten amount, placebo type, and challenge duration. One trial found no symptom association when FODMAPs were reduced, and two reported symptom worsening during placebo.
population_specificity: Adults with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or other FGIDs diagnosed by Rome II, III, or IV criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether patients with non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS) could tolerate gluten after reintroducing it into their diet following a gluten-free period.
results_summary: The study evaluated gastrointestinal symptoms and quality of life in NCGS patients after reintroducing gluten, comparing different gluten intake levels. Results indicated varying tolerance levels among patients, with some experiencing symptom recurrence.
population_specificity: 22 NCGS patients with functional gastroenterological symptoms.
study_duration: 3 weeks on gluten-free diet, followed by incremental gluten reintroduction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current information on non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS), its clinical and pathological manifestations, and challenges faced by health professionals and patients adopting a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that NCGS affects heterogeneous patient subgroups with varying clinical and pathological manifestations, and identified potential underlying factors for susceptibility. It also highlighted the lack of reliable biomarkers for NCGS diagnosis and noted that gluten-free products often have high fat and sugar content.
population_specificity: Patients with non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review literature on adherence to a gluten-free diet (GFD) in people with coeliac disease (CD) and the methodological challenges in assessing adherence.
results_summary: Adherence to a GFD in CD patients ranged between 45-90%, influenced by factors like age at diagnosis, depression, nutrition counseling, and food availability. Only five intervention studies aimed at improving adherence were identified, involving dietary/psychological counseling and digital tools.
population_specificity: People with coeliac disease (CD) of different ethnicities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the nutritional status of children with celiac disease at diagnosis and assess how a gluten-free diet (GFD) influences their growth.
results_summary: The study found that the nutritional status of celiac patients at diagnosis varies, with an increasing number being overweight or obese. GFD had a beneficial impact on growth, correcting BMI distribution towards a Gaussian shape.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (children) with celiac disease.
study_duration: Variable period from 1 to 17 years of GFD

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the appropriateness, safety, benefits, and side effects of a gluten-free diet for various clinical conditions beyond celiac disease.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that a gluten-free diet is safe and effective for celiac disease and other gluten-related disorders but raises questions about its benefits for non-celiac conditions like IBS, autism, and neurological diseases. It also discusses concerns about the safety and quality of gluten-free products.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease, non-celiac gluten sensitivity, irritable bowel syndrome, autism, neurological, psychiatric, and rheumatologic diseases, and general population.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to define key diagnostic and monitoring modalities for celiac disease (CD) in adults, children, and adolescents, including the role of a gluten-free diet (GFD) in management.
results_summary: The study found that serology, particularly TG2-IgA, is crucial for CD diagnosis, and a GFD is central to management, though serology has limited sensitivity for monitoring mucosal healing. Persistently positive serology usually indicates ongoing gluten exposure and intestinal damage.
population_specificity: Adults, children, and adolescents with or suspected of having celiac disease.
effective_dosage: Not specified (general recommendation to avoid gluten).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether reduced-gluten wheat bread and pasta produced via sourdough fermentation could alleviate symptoms in IBS patients compared to traditional gluten-containing products.
results_summary: The study found that a reduced-gluten diet decreased symptom severity in IBS patients compared to a normal-gluten diet, as measured by the Visual Analogue Scale score. The sensory features of the reduced-gluten products were similar to traditional ones.
population_specificity: Patients with Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
study_duration: 2 weeks per diet phase, with a 1-week washout period

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the clinical progress in celiac disease (CD) research and provide a guide on the role of a gluten-free diet (GFD) as the primary treatment.
results_summary: The study confirms that a lifelong gluten-free diet is the standard treatment for CD, effectively managing symptoms and preventing complications like autoimmunity and intestinal lymphoma. Adjunctive therapies are under development but not yet established.
population_specificity: Genetically predisposed individuals with celiac disease (HLA DQ2/DQ8 positive).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of intestinal microbiota in the pathogenesis, progression, and clinical presentation of celiac disease (CD) and its potential interaction with a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that intestinal microbiota imbalances are associated with CD, characterized by increased abundance of certain microbes, but does not provide specific findings on the effects of a gluten-free diet.
population_specificity: Genetically predisposed individuals with celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current state of research on gluten-free diet thresholds, its appropriateness for asymptomatic or potential celiac disease patients, and the lifelong necessity of the diet.
results_summary: The study highlights ambiguities in gluten-free diet implementation, including unclear tolerable gluten thresholds and its necessity for asymptomatic patients. It also suggests some patients may develop gluten tolerance over time.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease, including asymptomatic or potential celiac disease subgroups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of the prebiotic oligofructose-enriched inulin (Synergy 1) on fat-soluble vitamins status, parathormone, and calcium-related elements in pediatric celiac disease patients.
results_summary: The study assessed the impact of Synergy 1 on nutrient absorption in pediatric celiac disease patients, but specific results regarding Gluten-Free Diet were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Pediatric celiac disease patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a gluten-free diet (GFD) could effectively improve mood symptoms in individuals with or without gluten-related disorders.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that a gluten-free diet significantly improved depressive symptom scores in treated patients (SMD -0.37, 95% CI -0.55 to -0.20). The study included three randomized-controlled trials and 10 longitudinal studies with 1139 participants.
population_specificity: Patients with or without gluten-related disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential role of gluten in the development of type 1 and type 2 diabetes and the effects of a gluten-free diet in mitigating these risks.
results_summary: The study found that gluten may contribute to inflammatory conditions and beta-cell stress, potentially increasing diabetes risk. A gluten-free diet during pregnancy was linked to reduced type 1 diabetes risk, while evidence for type 2 diabetes was less clear but suggested possible benefits in reducing obesity and insulin resistance.
population_specificity: Animal studies and one human study (pregnant individuals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet (GFD) as the only treatment for celiac disease and the methods used to monitor compliance and outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that a strict and permanent GFD is the only effective treatment for celiac disease, with compliance rates around 50%. Monitoring methods include clinical follow-up, serological tests, endoscopies, and questionnaires, with children achieving mucosal normalization within two years and adults taking 3-5 years.
population_specificity: People with celiac disease, including children and adults, with a slight predominance in females.
study_duration: Varies by individual (2 years for children, 3-5 years for adults)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the mineral content (Ca, Fe, Mg, Zn) in gluten-free grain products worldwide and assess their adequacy in meeting dietary requirements.
results_summary: The study found that gluten-free products often lack sufficient minerals (Ca, Fe, Mg, Zn) due to poor mineral content in raw materials, potentially leading to deficiencies in individuals on a gluten-free diet. It classified products as rich, average, or poor sources of these minerals.
population_specificity: People on a gluten-free diet, dietitians, and food producers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence on the role of gluten in multiple sclerosis (MS) and the effects of a gluten-free diet on MS-related markers.
results_summary: The study found mixed results, with some intervention and observational studies suggesting a positive effect of a gluten-free diet on MS-related markers, while others found no significant association between gluten sensitivity and MS.
population_specificity: Patients with MS, clinically isolated syndrome, or celiac disease presenting with MS-related markers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of oligofructose-enriched inulin (Synergy 1) on iron homeostasis in non-anemic children and adolescents with celiac disease (CD) while on a gluten-free diet (GFD).
results_summary: The study found that serum hepcidin concentration significantly decreased by 60.9% after three months of Synergy 1 supplementation, suggesting improved iron homeostasis in CD patients on a GFD. No significant adverse effects were reported, but the abstract does not detail safety outcomes.
population_specificity: Non-anemic children and adolescents (4–18 years old) with celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a Gluten-Free Diet (GFD) on components of metabolic syndrome (MES).
results_summary: The study found that a short-term GFD significantly reduced fasting blood glucose, waist circumference, and serum triglyceride levels compared to a regular diet, but had no significant effects on LDL cholesterol, total cholesterol, fasting insulin, HOMA-IR, or blood pressure.
population_specificity: 50 subjects diagnosed with metabolic syndrome (45 completed the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adherence to a gluten-free diet (GFD) improves outcomes for patients with schizophrenia.
results_summary: Six of the nine included studies showed beneficial effects, such as improved functioning and reduced symptom severity with a GFD, while three found no benefits. All studies reported that a GFD was well tolerated and feasible for patients with schizophrenia.
population_specificity: Patients with schizophrenia.
study_duration: Varied by study (not specified in abstract)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the variability in the effects of a gluten-free diet (GFD) on gut microbiota and health, emphasizing the need for population-specific studies rather than generalizing results.
results_summary: The study found that the effects of GFD on gut microbiota and health are highly individualized and cannot be extrapolated across populations due to variability in microbial composition, diet composition, and economic factors. It calls for more localized research to improve health outcomes for those with gluten-related disorders.
population_specificity: Patients with gluten-related disorders (GRD) and healthy individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical and serological characteristics of children with ultra-short celiac disease (USCD) and those with extensive celiac disease (CD) under a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: Children with USCD showed milder symptoms, lower celiac serology, and faster normalization of anti-TTG antibodies under a gluten-free diet compared to those with extensive CD. The gluten-free diet was effective in normalizing serological markers, though the study did not assess long-term outcomes.
population_specificity: Children diagnosed with celiac disease (CD), specifically comparing those with ultra-short celiac disease (USCD) to those with extensive CD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an enzyme mixture could improve symptoms of non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS) by aiding gluten digestion.
results_summary: The enzyme mixture significantly reduced symptom scores (particularly incomplete evacuation and headaches) compared to placebo, with no adverse events reported. The mixture did not affect inflammatory markers like IL-8, TNF-α, or RANTES.
population_specificity: Patients with non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS) confirmed via screening, medical evaluations, and gluten challenge tests.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of a gluten-free diet in managing gluten ataxia (GA) as part of immune-mediated cerebellar ataxias (IMCAs).
results_summary: The study suggests that a gluten-free diet is a priority intervention for gluten ataxia, alongside immunotherapies, to prevent disease progression. Early treatment, including dietary changes, is associated with better prognosis when cerebellar atrophy is mild.
population_specificity: Patients with immune-mediated cerebellar ataxias, specifically gluten ataxia (GA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare demographics, diagnoses, symptoms, and treatment adherence between celiac disease patients diagnosed via biopsy versus serology.
results_summary: Patients diagnosed by serology (without biopsy) were more likely to be diagnosed by non-gastroenterologists, less likely to seek nutritional counseling, and more likely to use digestive supplements compared to biopsy-diagnosed patients.
population_specificity: Adults with celiac disease (mean age 43.4 years; 85.6% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish clinical guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of celiac disease in Mexico, emphasizing the necessity of a strict gluten-free diet for confirmed cases.
results_summary: The study confirmed that a strict gluten-free diet is essential for individuals with celiac disease, while its role in non-celiac gluten-sensitive patients remains debated. The guidelines also established diagnostic standards and treatment recommendations for Mexican patients.
population_specificity: Individuals with celiac disease in Mexico, including high-risk groups such as first-degree relatives and those with autoimmune diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of a gluten-free diet in reducing IgA antigliadin antibodies and proteinuria in patients with IgA nephropathy (IgAN).
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet reduced IgA antigliadin antibodies and proteinuria in IgAN patients. Additionally, dietary gluten was shown to regulate IgAN in transgenic mice expressing human IgA1 and sCD89.
population_specificity: Patients with IgA nephropathy (IgAN) and transgenic mice models.
study_duration: Not specified for human trials; 9 months for the NEFIGAN trial (though this involved budesonide, not gluten-free diet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the association between gluten-related disorders (celiac disease and non-celiac gluten sensitivity) and autoimmune manifestations, particularly myasthenia gravis, and the role of a Gluten-Free Diet in symptom improvement.
results_summary: The study found that gluten-related disorders can present with various immune-mediated morbidities, including rare associations like myasthenia gravis. A Gluten-Free Diet was noted to improve symptoms in non-celiac gluten sensitivity cases without enteropathy.
population_specificity: A young female patient initially presenting with peripheral neuropathy, later developing symptoms of immune-mediated morbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a case of dermatitis herpetiformis with facial involvement and assess the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet combined with topical dapsone in treating the condition.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet, along with topical dapsone 5% gel, effectively cleared the pruritic vesicles in a patient with dermatitis herpetiformis. The case highlights the potential for facial involvement in this condition and the therapeutic role of a gluten-free diet.
population_specificity: A 44-year-old woman with dermatitis herpetiformis misdiagnosed as allergic contact dermatitis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (gluten-free diet only, no dosage mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the current medical literature on movement disorders related to gluten sensitivity and evaluate the benefits of a gluten-free diet in such cases.
results_summary: The review found that gluten-related movement disorders extend beyond gluten ataxia and that a gluten-free diet is beneficial in a significant percentage of these cases.
population_specificity: Individuals with gluten sensitivity and related movement disorders, with or without enteropathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prevalence of celiac disease in infertile women undergoing IVF and assess whether a gluten-free diet improved IVF outcomes.
results_summary: The study found no association between a gluten-free diet and improved IVF outcomes, including oocyte retrieval, fertilization, blastulation, or pregnancy rates. Seropositive celiac patients had equivalent outcomes to seronegative patients.
population_specificity: Women aged 18-45 undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF) at a single infertility center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in visceral fat area in the general population after 6 weeks of consuming gluten-free, gluten-containing, and whole-grain bakery products.
results_summary: Visceral fat area increased slightly in the gluten-free and gluten-containing groups but was not significant, while the whole-grain and control groups showed reductions. The number of subjects with reference values of visceral fat area improved in the gluten-free and gluten-containing groups but decreased in the whole-grain group.
population_specificity: 120 volunteers divided into four subgroups of 30 subjects each from the general population.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of a gluten-free diet (GFD) in managing coeliac disease (CD), including diagnostic criteria, patient compliance challenges, and the prevalence of persistent symptoms despite adherence to GFD.
results_summary: The study found that while a GFD is effective for most CD patients, up to 20% experience persistent or recurrent symptoms, often due to inadvertent gluten exposure. Maintaining a GFD is challenging for patients, highlighting the need to understand barriers to compliance.
population_specificity: Individuals with coeliac disease (CD), including children and adults, with varying clinical presentations from malabsorption to asymptomatic cases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the importance of recognizing celiac disease in individuals with non-gastrointestinal symptoms and the potential benefits of an early-initiated gluten-free diet in preventing severe complications.
results_summary: The study found that unrecognized celiac disease may predispose individuals to severe complications, and an early-initiated gluten-free diet could help prevent these outcomes. However, the pathogenesis and long-term effects of extraintestinal manifestations remain poorly understood.
population_specificity: Individuals with celiac disease, particularly those with non-gastrointestinal symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a low FODMAP gluten-free diet (LF-GFD) on gastrointestinal and psychological symptoms in celiac disease patients with persistent symptoms despite a standard gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that a low FODMAP gluten-free diet improved gastrointestinal symptoms in celiac disease patients who continued to experience symptoms on a standard gluten-free diet. The abstract does not provide detailed results on psychological symptomatology.
population_specificity: 50 celiac disease patients on a gluten-free diet with persistent gastrointestinal symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the immunological and clinical challenges of managing a gluten-free diet (GFD) in patients with coexisting type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) and celiac disease (CD).
results_summary: The study highlights that GFD impacts glycemic control, bone health, and vascular complications in T1DM and CD patients, with intermittent gluten intake exacerbating immune responses. It underscores the need for strict adherence to GFD but notes challenges in compliance.
population_specificity: Patients with coexisting type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) and celiac disease (CD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a gluten-free diet affects thyroid autoimmunity, hypothalamic-pituitary-thyroid axis activity, and thyroid function tests in women with Hashimoto's thyroiditis and positive anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies.
results_summary: The gluten-free diet reduced thyroid antibody titers, slightly increased 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels, and improved the SPINA-GT index, while no significant changes were observed in the control group. The diet's impact on antibody levels correlated with changes in the SPINA-GT index and 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels.
population_specificity: 34 women with autoimmune thyroiditis and positive anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of oligofructose-enriched inulin (Synergy 1) as a gluten-free diet supplement on plasma and urine amino acid concentrations in children with celiac disease.
results_summary: The study found that Synergy 1 supplementation increased plasma concentrations of several amino acids and altered urinary excretion patterns, suggesting improved absorption or metabolism. The Gln:Glu ratio in urine increased in both groups, indicating potential benefits for intestinal health.
population_specificity: Children with celiac disease (N=34)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic efficiency of a gluten-free diet and identify its drawbacks, including compliance issues, nutritional deficits, and effects on intestinal microbiota.
results_summary: The study found that while gluten-free diets are effective for treating celiac disease and other gluten-related disorders, they have drawbacks such as nutritional deficiencies and altered gut microbiota. Food science interventions, particularly sourdough fermentation, show promise in mitigating these issues.
population_specificity: Individuals with celiac disease, other gluten-related disorders, and wellbeing people without medical prescriptions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore two approaches—food processing and wheat breeding—to reduce gluten immunogenicity for coeliac disease patients.
results_summary: The study found that existing food processing techniques could produce low-immunogenic wheat products, and wheat breeding strategies could potentially create coeliac-safe wheat while maintaining food-processing properties. A combination of breeding methods, including mutation breeding and genome editing, may be necessary to achieve this goal.
population_specificity: Individuals with coeliac disease (CD) and those genetically susceptible to developing CD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the predictors and significance of long-term follow-up in coeliac disease patients on a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: Only 15% of patients had long-term follow-up, with comparable outcomes between those with and without follow-up in terms of diet adherence, symptom frequency, and seropositivity, though those without follow-up reported more overall symptoms. Most patients desired follow-up, suggesting a need for personalized policies.
population_specificity: 677 previously diagnosed coeliac disease patients in a nationwide health survey.
study_duration: Median follow-up duration was 10 years for those with long-term follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and discuss the current literature on celiac disease in childhood, focusing on diagnostic methods and the effectiveness of a lifelong gluten-free diet as therapy.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet is the lifelong therapy for celiac disease, with good prognosis in children and no complications. Diagnostic screening involves serum anti-tissue transglutaminase IgA levels, with biopsies required in uncertain cases.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the spectrum of gluten-related disorders, including non-coeliac gluten sensitivity (NCGS), and discuss recent evidence on NCGS diagnosis and clinical care.
results_summary: The study highlights that NCGS is a poorly understood condition with inconsistent evidence regarding gluten's role in symptom triggers, suggesting other wheat components may be involved. It calls for standardized diagnostic procedures to optimize clinical care.
population_specificity: Individuals with gluten-related disorders (coeliac disease, wheat allergy, and non-coeliac gluten sensitivity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prevalence of celiac disease (CD) in children with cryptogenic cirrhosis and assess the effects of a gluten-free diet (GFD) on liver function in these patients.
results_summary: The study found that 13.1% of children with cryptogenic cirrhosis had CD. After 6 months of GFD, the CD group showed improvements in hemoglobin levels, liver function tests, and Child-Pugh scores.
population_specificity: Children under 18 years old with cryptogenic cirrhosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of faecal gluten immunogenic peptides (GIP) as a biomarker for monitoring gluten intake and assessing compliance to a gluten-free diet (GFD) in children with coeliac disease.
results_summary: The study found that GIP detection was more sensitive than clinical assessment, tTG levels, or Biagi score in identifying recent gluten consumption. GIP levels decreased significantly after GFD initiation, but detectable GIP persisted in some patients, indicating noncompliance. Combining methods did not improve noncompliance detection.
population_specificity: 63 children with coeliac disease (44 previously diagnosed, 19 newly diagnosed).
study_duration: Follow-up at 6 and 12 months after GFD initiation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review developments in biosensor technology for detecting celiac disease biomarkers, which is used to monitor the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet as therapy.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that biosensors offer a promising, non-invasive method for detecting celiac disease biomarkers, emphasizing their potential for sensitive, selective, and stable detection compared to conventional techniques.
population_specificity: Genetically-susceptible individuals with celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of point-of-care tests (POCTs) for celiac disease (CD), including their sensitivity and specificity, to determine their potential as screening tools.
results_summary: The study found that POCTs for diagnosing CD had high pooled sensitivity (94.0%) and specificity (94.4%), with IgA-tTG-based POCTs showing slightly lower sensitivity (90.5%) but similar specificity (94.8%). The results suggest POCTs are effective for CD screening, particularly in resource-limited settings.
population_specificity: Individuals suspected of having celiac disease, as diagnosed by villous atrophy, positive celiac-specific serology, or clinical improvement after a gluten-free diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of celiac disease on bone health and provide guidance on monitoring and managing bone health in these patients, including the role of a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that celiac disease negatively affects bone health due to inflammation and malabsorption of calcium and vitamin D. A strict gluten-free diet, along with calcium and vitamin D supplementation and weight-bearing exercises, was recommended to improve bone health.
population_specificity: Adults and children with celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the understanding, diagnostic strategies, and management of celiac disease, including the role of a gluten-free diet and its challenges.
results_summary: The study highlights the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet in managing celiac disease but notes challenges like refractory cases and non-responsive conditions. It also discusses the variability in symptoms between pediatric and adult populations and the importance of comprehensive nutritional management.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease, including those with varying risk levels (general population, symptomatic patients, and those with family history).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess cardiac function in children with celiac disease and evaluate the impact of a gluten-free diet on cardiac function.
results_summary: Untreated celiac disease children showed impaired cardiac function, which improved significantly after one year of a gluten-free diet, particularly in compliant patients. Non-compliant children continued to exhibit persistent cardiac dysfunction.
population_specificity: Children with celiac disease (ages 4.2 ± 1.1 years) and healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether gluten-free diets, among other dietary therapies, could benefit IBS patients.
results_summary: The abstract suggests emerging data indicates gluten-free diets might be beneficial for IBS patients, though the primary focus and stronger evidence support FODMAP restriction.
population_specificity: IBS patients associating symptoms with eating.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of a gluten-free diet in managing celiac disease symptoms in a pediatric patient with a complex diagnostic history.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet significantly improved the patient's clinical and laboratory outcomes after one month, following previous misdiagnoses and ineffective treatments. The case highlights the diagnostic challenges of celiac disease in young children with insufficient gluten exposure.
population_specificity: 1-year-old male child with a history of idiopathic pericardial effusion and enterocolitis with enteropathogenic E. coli.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a probiotic mixture in celiac disease patients with IBS-type symptoms despite adhering to a strict gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The probiotic treatment significantly reduced IBS-SSS and GSRS scores compared to placebo, improved treatment success rates, and increased beneficial gut bacteria like bifidobacteria, with no reported adverse events.
population_specificity: Celiac disease patients with IBS-type symptoms despite a strict gluten-free diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the health impact of celiac disease (CD) and non-gluten sensitivity (NCGS) and assess the role of a gluten-free diet (GFD) in managing these conditions.
results_summary: The study found a moderately increased mortality risk in CD patients, primarily due to cardiovascular disease and malignancy, but noted that strict adherence to a GFD substantially improved or completely treated many long-term morbidities, including autoimmune disorders, nutritional deficiencies, and neurologic issues. For NCGS, long-term complications remain unknown due to limited literature.
population_specificity: Patients with biopsy-proven celiac disease (CD) and non-gluten sensitivity (NCGS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze hemorrhagic events in adult celiac disease (CD) patients and assess the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet in managing these conditions.
results_summary: The study found that hemorrhagic events, though rare, can occur in CD patients, with gastrointestinal bleeding being the most common. A gluten-free diet led to favorable outcomes in most cases.
population_specificity: Adult celiac disease patients (aged 19-74 years, 64% male) with hemorrhagic manifestations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a low FODMAP diet versus a gluten-free diet (GFD) on clinical symptoms, psychological well-being, intestinal inflammation, and stool microbiota in patients with non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS).
results_summary: The GFD significantly improved clinical and psychological symptoms in NCGS patients, reduced duodenal intraepithelial lymphocytes and mucin-producing Goblet cells, and caused microbial shifts in stool samples. Both diets led to microbial changes, with greater variability in NCGS patients.
population_specificity: Nineteen patients with NCGS and ten healthy controls.
study_duration: Two weeks for each diet (low FODMAP and GFD), with a five-day transition period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the epidemiological, clinical, laboratory, and histologic characteristics of children with celiac disease at diagnosis and on follow-up, focusing on the effects of a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet led to clinical improvement in 100% of patients (51% complete, 49% partial), normalized IgA tTG in 45% after 12-30 months, and improved growth metrics (height increase in 100%, weight gain in 96%).
population_specificity: Children aged 1-17 years (mean 8.5±4.5 years, 69% girls) with previously established or newly diagnosed celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically summarize recent work on seronegative coeliac disease (SCD) and provide a definition for it, focusing on its diagnostic challenges and implications for gluten-free diet intervention.
results_summary: The study found that SCD is rare among coeliac patients but a common cause of seronegative villous atrophy, emphasizing the need for accurate diagnosis before initiating a lifelong gluten-free diet to avoid inappropriate treatment and long-term morbidity. It also suggested that seronegative enteropathies may have higher mortality than conventional coeliac disease.
population_specificity: Patients with seronegative villous atrophy or suspected seronegative coeliac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the extent of accidental gluten consumption among celiac disease patients adhering to a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that celiac disease patients on a gluten-free diet inadvertently consume significant amounts of gluten (mean 150-400 mg/day, median 100-150 mg/day), enough to trigger symptoms and cause intestinal damage. Surrogate biomarkers confirmed regular gluten exposure despite dietary adherence.
population_specificity: Celiac disease patients adhering to a gluten-free diet, including those with moderate to severe symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if ANPEP-treated wheat bread could be suitable for gluten-sensitive individuals by reducing immunogenic gluten content while maintaining bread quality.
results_summary: ANPEP reduced immunogenic gluten by ~40% in treated bread, but no significant reduction in GI symptoms was observed compared to control bread. GS subjects had improved cardiovascular lipid profiles but no changes in quality of life, fatigue, or mental state.
population_specificity: Adults self-reporting benefits from a gluten-free or low-gluten diet (n=16) and a non-GS control group (n=12).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet in reducing allergic reactions in patients with omega-5 gliadin allergy.
results_summary: The study found that patients adhering to a gluten-free diet achieved a 67% reduction in subsequent allergic reactions. Avoidance of wheat in combination with exercise (if exercise was a cofactor) also significantly reduced reactions by 69%.
population_specificity: 132 patients with omega-5 gliadin allergy from 4 UK centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of oligofructose-enriched inulin (Synergy 1) on intestinal microbiota characteristics and metabolism in children with celiac disease following a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that Synergy 1 administration in a gluten-free diet did not cause side effects and may help restore gut homeostasis, though specific efficacy results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Pediatric celiac disease patients (mean age 10 years; 62% females) on a gluten-free diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet as the primary treatment for coeliac disease and explore alternative therapies under development.
results_summary: The study confirms that a gluten-free diet is the only accepted treatment for coeliac disease but notes reduced quality of life and common dietary transgressions. It also reviews emerging therapies targeting different pathogenic mechanisms of the disease.
population_specificity: Individuals with coeliac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic role of a gluten-free diet (GFD) in celiac disease and nonceliac gluten sensitivity (NCGS), including its benefits and potential nutritional complications.
results_summary: A GFD heals celiac disease enteropathy and improves symptoms in NCGS, but long-term adherence may lead to nutritional deficiencies requiring monitoring.
population_specificity: Genetically predisposed individuals with celiac disease and individuals with nonceliac gluten sensitivity (NCGS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review available therapies for coeliac disease (CD) and assess the challenges and future directions of gluten-free diet (GFD) as a treatment.
results_summary: The study found that while GFD remains the primary treatment for CD, its efficacy is challenged by availability, palatability, and practicality. The only promising alternative to GFD is a vaccine inducing tolerance.
population_specificity: Patients with coeliac disease (CD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the association between celiac disease and aplastic anemia in a pediatric patient and assess the impact of a gluten-free diet on managing the condition.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet, alongside other treatments, led to improving platelet counts in a pediatric patient with celiac disease and pancytopenia. The case suggests a potential association between celiac disease and aplastic anemia, warranting further investigation.
population_specificity: 6-year-old South Asian girl with celiac disease and pancytopenia.
study_duration: Yearly follow-ups (exact duration of gluten-free diet intervention not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential role of a gluten-free diet in managing collagenous enteritis, particularly in relation to its pathogenesis and response to treatment.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet, along with discontinuation of olmesartan and steroid treatments, resulted in symptomatic and histologic improvement in collagenous enteritis patients. However, most subjects lacked celiac disease-associated autoantibodies, suggesting a distinct pathogenesis from celiac disease.
population_specificity: Elderly subjects (median age 69 years) with biopsy-proven collagenous enteritis.

study_goal: To review the occurrence, clinical features, diagnosis, and management of coeliac disease in elderly patients and assess the benefits of a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: Approximately 25% of coeliac disease diagnoses occur in patients aged 60 or older, with 60% remaining undetected due to subtle symptoms. Over 90% of patients showed good compliance with a gluten-free diet, resolution of symptoms, and improved lab indices.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (60+ years) with coeliac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize key dietary interventions for gastrointestinal disorders and assess the nutritional implications of a gluten-free diet, particularly its necessity in celiac disease and perceived benefits in other conditions.
results_summary: The gluten-free diet negatively influences overall diet quality but is essential for celiac disease. Its use for other perceived health benefits should be weighed against potential nutritional risks, such as compromised intake of fiber, iron, and calcium.
population_specificity: Individuals with gastrointestinal disorders, particularly celiac disease and irritable bowel syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on cognitive impairments associated with celiac disease (CD) and non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS) and assess the potential protective effects of a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that cognitive impairments in CD and NCGS vary in severity and prognosis, with mechanisms including nutritional deficiencies and systemic inflammation. A gluten-free diet, though controversial, may have a protective effect if introduced early.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease (CD) or non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS) experiencing cognitive impairments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the prevalence of gluten-free diet (GFD) use in children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and identify characteristics associated with GFD usage.
results_summary: The study found that 11.1% of children with ASD were currently on a GFD, and 20.4% had ever used one, significantly higher than in the control population. GFD usage was associated with gastrointestinal conditions and developmental regression in children with ASD.
population_specificity: Children aged 30-68 months with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and population controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the prevalence and diagnostic challenges of non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS) and the growing market for gluten-free products.
results_summary: The study highlights the lack of reliable biomarkers for NCGS and the reliance on symptom-based diagnosis, while noting the significant market growth for gluten-free products driven by consumer misconceptions.
population_specificity: United States population, including individuals with celiac disease and non-celiac gluten sensitivity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether stepwise dose escalation of Nexvax2, a peptide-based immunotherapy, could attenuate adverse effects and improve tolerance to gluten in celiac disease patients on a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: Stepwise dose escalation allowed higher maintenance doses (up to 900μg) without triggering adverse immune responses, reducing gastrointestinal symptoms and cytokine release. Nexvax2 showed trends toward improved duodenal histology and dose-dependent plasma concentrations.
population_specificity: HLA-DQ2.5 genotype-positive adults with celiac disease on a gluten-free diet, divided into homozygotes (cohort 1) and non-homozygotes (cohorts 2 and 3).
effective_dosage: Escalating doses from 3μg to 900μg, administered every 3-4 days over 7-9 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of a gluten-free diet as the primary treatment for celiac disease and its diagnostic challenges in patients with gluten-related symptoms but without celiac disease.
results_summary: The study found that strict adherence to a gluten-free diet is effective for managing celiac disease, while patients with gluten-related symptoms but no celiac disease may require additional evaluations like nutritional improvements or testing for small intestinal bacterial overgrowth.
population_specificity: Genetically predisposed individuals with celiac disease and those with gluten-related symptoms but without celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic options for eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) and celiac disease (CeD), focusing on the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet for CeD.
results_summary: The study found that a strict gluten-free diet is the only effective therapy for celiac disease, leading to remission, while multiple options exist for EoE. New biologic therapies are under investigation but not yet clinically available.
population_specificity: Patients with eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) and celiac disease (CeD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a gluten-free diet (GFD) on modifiable cardiovascular risk factors, particularly in patients with celiac disease.
results_summary: The study found that a GFD led to increases in total cholesterol, high-density lipoprotein, fasting glycaemia, and body mass index (though within healthy ranges), but inconsistent changes in low-density lipoprotein, triglycerides, and blood pressure. The overall effect on cardiovascular risk remains unclear.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize risk factors for gluten-free diet (GFD) nonadherence, nonadherence rates, and current intervention research, while developing a research agenda for evidence-based GFD adherence interventions.
results_summary: Pediatric studies showed GFD nonadherence rates ranging from 19 to 56%, with few evidence-based interventions available. Nonmodifiable and modifiable factors across individual, family, community, and health systems domains must be considered for future interventions.
population_specificity: Pediatric samples

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet in managing celiac disease symptoms and propose an approach for patients with persistent symptoms despite the diet.
results_summary: The study found that while most celiac disease patients improve on a gluten-free diet, up to 30% may show persistent symptoms or intestinal damage after one year, requiring further evaluation and potential dietary adjustments.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of a gluten-free diet as a complementary treatment for neuropathic corneal pain (NCP).
results_summary: The study suggests that a gluten-free diet may offer additional benefits for NCP patients, but it does not provide specific efficacy data or statistical evidence supporting its use.
population_specificity: Patients with neuropathic corneal pain (NCP).

study_goal: The researchers examined the association between exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (EPI) and conditions like celiac disease, and the role of a gluten-free diet in resolving EPI.
results_summary: The study found that EPI occurs in untreated celiac disease (4%-80%) but typically resolves on a gluten-free diet, suggesting its efficacy in managing EPI in this context.
population_specificity: Patients with untreated celiac disease and EPI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential benefits of a gluten-free diet for psoriatic patients, given the association between psoriasis and celiac disease.
results_summary: The study suggests a potential benefit from a gluten-free diet among psoriatic patients, linked to shared pathogenesis like vitamin D deficiency, immune pathways, and increased intestinal permeability. However, no specific clinical outcomes or statistical results are provided.
population_specificity: Psoriatic patients, particularly those with associated conditions like celiac disease or inflammatory bowel diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe existing knowledge about food-related activities, participation, and quality of life in daily life among children and adolescents with celiac disease (CD) adhering to a gluten-free diet, and to identify gaps in knowledge.
results_summary: The study identified 55 different food-related activities and highlighted challenges in daily functioning for children and adolescents with CD. It emphasized the need for further research to develop standardized assessment tools and intervention programs.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of mesalazine and a gluten-free diet (GFD) in treating gluten-induced inflammation and oxidative stress in celiac disease patients.
results_summary: The study found that mesalazine was as effective as GFD in reducing oxidative burst and inducing PPARγ expression, and more effective than GFD in decreasing NF-kB and NOS2 levels to control levels.
population_specificity: Newly diagnosed celiac disease patients, patients on a gluten-free diet for at least one year, and healthy controls.
study_duration: Not specified for GFD; in vitro treatment duration not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential link between gluten-related conditions and severe mental illnesses and assess the efficacy of gluten-free diets for individuals with psychosis and mood disorders.
results_summary: The review found insufficient evidence to support the use of gluten-free diets for populations with psychosis and mood disorders, despite a slightly higher risk of these conditions in people with celiac disease or gluten allergy. The data revealed significant inaccuracies, limiting definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Individuals with severe mental illnesses (psychosis, schizophrenia, mood disorders, bipolar disorder, depression).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether supplementing a gluten-free diet with oligofructose-enriched inulin (Synergy 1) could improve gastrointestinal symptoms, nutritional status, and gut microbiota balance in children with celiac disease.
results_summary: The study hypothesized that Synergy 1 supplementation would alleviate intestinal inflammation, restore gut microbial balance, and enhance nutrient absorption, but the abstract does not provide specific results from the trial.
population_specificity: 34 children diagnosed with celiac disease following a gluten-free diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current evidence on screening, diagnosis, and treatment for celiac disease and nonceliac gluten sensitivity, focusing on the role of a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet is effective for managing both celiac disease and nonceliac gluten sensitivity, though distinguishing between the two conditions is crucial for long-term therapy. Patients with celiac disease require close follow-up for dietary adherence and potential comorbidities.
population_specificity: Individuals with celiac disease or nonceliac gluten sensitivity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet in treating coeliac disease and explore challenges related to adherence and persistent symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet is effective for most individuals with coeliac disease, but a substantial minority experience persistent or recurrent symptoms. Non-dietary therapies are being developed due to adherence difficulties.
population_specificity: Individuals with coeliac disease, including both symptomatic and non-symptomatic presentations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate predictive factors for metabolic syndrome (MS) and hepatic steatosis (HS) in patients with coeliac disease (CD) after one year on a gluten-free diet (GFD).
results_summary: After one year on a GFD, 23.9% of patients developed MS and 37.2% developed HS. High BMI at diagnosis and proton pump inhibitor (PPI) exposure were significant risk factors for MS, while HOMA-IR and PPI exposure were linked to HS.
population_specificity: Newly diagnosed coeliac disease patients (n=301).
interactions: Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) were associated with increased risk of MS and HS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the diagnostic criteria for celiac disease in adults and the role of a gluten-free diet in confirming the diagnosis and managing symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet supports the diagnosis of celiac disease by relieving symptoms and improving histology, but diagnostic uncertainty may arise if testing is not performed while consuming gluten. Persistent symptoms despite treatment may require reevaluation of the diagnosis or diet.
population_specificity: Adults suspected of or diagnosed with celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether latiglutenase, an oral gluten-specific protease, could reduce symptoms in symptomatic celiac disease patients adhering to a gluten-free diet, particularly in seropositive subgroups.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant, dose-dependent reduction in symptom severity and frequency in seropositive patients, with abdominal pain and bloating reduced by 58% and 44%, respectively, at the highest dose (900 mg). Symptom improvement increased from week 6 to week 12, with greater improvement linked to higher baseline symptom severity.
population_specificity: Symptomatic celiac disease patients following a gluten-free diet for at least one year prior to randomization, with 43% seropositive at baseline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the lipid profiles of children with type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) and celiac disease (CD) and assess the influence of a gluten-free diet (GFD) on lipid changes.
results_summary: The study found that children with T1DM and CD had higher LDL cholesterol levels compared to those with T1DM alone, and GFD did not normalize LDL-C levels, even in adherent individuals. The youngest children showed lower total cholesterol at diagnosis and a greater decrease in triglycerides after GFD.
population_specificity: Children with both type 1 diabetes mellitus and biopsy-proven celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether hydrolysed wheat gluten, pre-treated with lactobacilli and fungal proteases, could reduce immunogenicity in coeliac patients compared to natural wheat gluten.
results_summary: Hydrolysed wheat gluten did not activate T cells in coeliac intestinal mucosa or increase INF-γ secretion in patients, while natural wheat gluten did. The study confirmed that fermentation with lactobacilli and proteases abolishes gluten's T cell immunogenicity in coeliac patients.
population_specificity: Twenty treated coeliac disease patients.
effective_dosage: 10 g of gluten per day for 3 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between Coeliac Disease (CD) and severe rhabdomyolysis in children and assess the effectiveness of a Gluten-Free Diet (GFD) in resolving symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that a Gluten-Free Diet normalized jejunal histology and resolved symptoms in a child with CD-associated rhabdomyolysis, suggesting GFD as an effective treatment. The literature review supported the rarity of this association but highlighted its clinical significance.
population_specificity: A 3-year-old boy with CD-associated rhabdomyolysis; literature review included cases aged 12-75 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on vaccine response in pediatric celiac disease (CD) patients and provide clinical practice guidelines for monitoring vaccine efficacy in this population.
results_summary: The study found that the immunological response to vaccines in CD children is generally similar to the general population, with adequate antibody titers for long-term protection, except for the hepatitis B virus vaccine.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe gluten-related disorders (celiac disease, wheat allergy, nonceliac gluten sensitivity) and the role of a gluten-free diet as the current treatment for celiac disease.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that a gluten-free diet is the only available treatment for celiac disease, while other potential treatments are under research. It also differentiates celiac disease from wheat allergy and nonceliac gluten sensitivity.
population_specificity: Genetically susceptible individuals with celiac disease, those with wheat allergy, and individuals with nonceliac gluten sensitivity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and pharmacodynamics of Nexvax2, a therapeutic vaccine designed to treat coeliac disease by modifying immune responsiveness to gluten peptides.
results_summary: The study found that Nexvax2 modified immune responsiveness without deteriorating duodenal histology, with gastrointestinal adverse events resembling those from gluten ingestion. Higher doses showed increased efficacy in reducing immune responses to gluten peptides.
population_specificity: HLA-DQ2·5-positive patients aged 18-70 years with coeliac disease on a gluten-free diet.
effective_dosage: 60 μg, 90 μg, 150 μg weekly (three-dose study); 150 μg or 300 μg twice weekly (16-dose study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the clinical disorders related to gluten or wheat ingestion and assess the current understanding, open questions, and management of gluten-related disorders.
results_summary: The study highlights the increased incidence of gluten-related disorders and frequent self-diagnosis leading to inappropriate adoption of a gluten-free diet. It identifies gluten and wheat as key triggers for celiac disease, wheat allergy, and non-celiac gluten sensitivity, emphasizing the need for proper diagnostic protocols.
population_specificity: General population, with specific mention of individuals with celiac disease, wheat allergy, and non-celiac gluten sensitivity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety of including oats in a gluten-free diet for patients with celiac disease by analyzing symptoms, serology, and histologic outcomes.
results_summary: The study found no evidence that adding oats to a gluten-free diet affected symptoms, histology, immunity, or serologic features in celiac disease patients, though the quality of evidence was low.
population_specificity: Patients with celiac disease (661 total, including adults and children).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of gluten and celiac disease on schizophrenia onset and the efficacy of gluten-free diets in improving symptoms.
results_summary: Some studies indicated symptom improvement in schizophrenia with gluten exclusion, but results were inconsistent across clinical, immunological, and epidemiological investigations. Increased anti-gliadin antibodies were found in schizophrenic patients without celiac disease, suggesting a potential immunological link.
population_specificity: Schizophrenic patients, particularly those with or without celiac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the burden of celiac disease in the U.S. and identify knowledge gaps, including the trade-offs between burden and benefit of a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The study found that celiac disease is prevalent and associated with significant morbidity, quality of life impact, and increased costs, but knowledge gaps remain regarding the epidemiologic burden, gluten-free diet trade-offs, and cost estimation.
population_specificity: Genetically susceptible individuals with celiac disease in the U.S.

study_goal: To review the evidence on benefits and harms of screening for celiac disease in asymptomatic individuals and assess the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet for screen-detected cases.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet led to small improvements in gastrointestinal symptoms in asymptomatic adults with screen-detected celiac disease, but no significant differences in most quality-of-life measures. Diagnostic tests like IgA tissue transglutaminase showed high accuracy, but sensitivity was lower in asymptomatic populations.
population_specificity: Asymptomatic adults, adolescents, and children 3 years and older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of a text message intervention (TEACH) on gluten-free diet adherence, patient activation, and quality of life among adolescents with celiac disease.
results_summary: The TEACH intervention significantly improved patient activation and quality of life but did not significantly affect gluten-free diet adherence, whether measured objectively or via patient reports.
population_specificity: Adolescents and young adults (ages 12-24) with celiac disease diagnosed at least one year prior.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (intervention was text messages, not a dietary dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize available studies on the follow-up of children with celiac disease (CD) to assess adherence to a gluten-free diet, nutritional adequacy, quality of life, and prevention of complications.
results_summary: The study found that regular clinical and biochemical evaluations are necessary for children with CD to ensure dietary adherence, nutritional adequacy, and early detection of complications. Yearly follow-ups at referral centers are recommended, including screening for micronutrient deficiencies and autoimmune thyroiditis.
population_specificity: Children with celiac disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety of microbial transglutaminase (mTG)-modified wheat flour ingestion in celiac disease (CD) patients as an alternative to a gluten-free diet (GFD).
results_summary: The study found that mTG-modified wheat flour resulted in fewer adverse immune responses and symptoms (e.g., abdominal swelling, bloating, nausea) compared to unmodified flour in CD patients, though some patients still showed positive serum markers and villous atrophy. The results suggest potential for enzymatic treatment as an alternative to GFD but require further validation.
population_specificity: Twenty-one celiac disease patients in remission.
